articles.headline: Kidnapping Victim Was Not Always Locked Away
articles.snippet: Jaycee Dugard, held captive by Phillip Garrido for 18 years, was introduced to visitors at her captor’s home.
articles.abstract: Jaycee Dugard, held captive by Phillip Garrido for 18 years, was introduced to visitors at her captor’s home.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  About a year ago, Ben Daughdrill drove to the home of Phillip Garrido near the Bay Area suburb of Antioch to check on a printing job he had hired Mr. Garrido to do.
articles.byline: By Jesse McKinley and Carol Pogash

articles.headline: Karzai Using Rift With U.S. to Gain Favor
articles.snippet: As American concerns mount about reports of widespread electoral fraud, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan is portraying himself as the candidate willing to stand up to the U.S.
articles.abstract: As American concerns mount about reports of widespread electoral fraud, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan is portraying himself as the candidate willing to stand up to the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAK BLUFFS, Mass.  A little over 24 hours after the polls closed, President Obama stepped out on the White House South Lawn last week to pronounce the Afghanistan presidential elections something of a success.

articles.headline: How Retirees Can Spend Enough, but Not Too Much
articles.snippet: One adviser offers a formula that helps retirees raise or lower their withdrawals depending on the performance of the stock market.
articles.abstract: One adviser offers a formula that helps retirees raise or lower their withdrawals depending on the performance of the stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you retire, you’ll probably want to visit your grandchildren more than once each year. Perhaps you’ll aim to give money each month to charity or your religious congregation.

articles.headline: It’s Time to Admit That Money Funds Involve Risk
articles.snippet: Money markets are investment vehicles, not bank savings accounts, which means (shudder) investors may sometimes lose money.
articles.abstract: Money markets are investment vehicles, not bank savings accounts, which means (shudder) investors may sometimes lose money.
articles.lead_paragraph: In all the inevitable hoopla surrounding the coming anniversary of “Lehman weekend”  those fateful days in mid-September 2008, when the financial world seemed on the brink of collapse  here’s an important event that will almost surely be overlooked:

articles.headline: Investors in Cerberus Seek to Pull $5.5 Billion
articles.snippet: The pessimism of the investors, 71 percent of those with stakes in the two Cerberus Partners funds, is another black eye for the firm.
articles.abstract: The pessimism of the investors, 71 percent of those with stakes in the two Cerberus Partners funds, is another black eye for the firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clients with more than $5.5 billion invested in hedge funds controlled by Cerberus Capital Management have told the firm that they want their money back.

articles.headline: Coupons You Don’t Clip, Sent to Your Cellphone
articles.snippet: Mobile coupons — usually text messages with discount codes sent to a cellphone — are becoming the blue-light specials for the digital age.
articles.abstract: Mobile coupons — usually text messages with discount codes sent to a cellphone — are becoming the blue-light specials for the digital age.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hunter Gilmore was never big on clipping coupons. “You stick them on the fridge, meaning to use them, and it never happens,” said Mr. Gilmore, a 29-year-old actor and advertising agency recruiter in Manhattan.

articles.headline: Reluctance to Spend May Be Legacy of Recession
articles.snippet: Even though consumer spending rose in July, many Americans are still watching their pennies, and some said their newfound frugality would not be temporary.
articles.abstract: Even though consumer spending rose in July, many Americans are still watching their pennies, and some said their newfound frugality would not be temporary.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.  Even as evidence mounts that the Great Recession has finally released its chokehold on the American economy, experts worry that the recovery may be weak, stymied by consumers’ reluctance to spend.

articles.headline: ‘Non-GMO’ Seal Identifies Foods Mostly Biotech-Free
articles.snippet: Many makers of organic and natural foods said their credibility depended on ensuring that their products were free of genetically altered ingredients.
articles.abstract: Many makers of organic and natural foods said their credibility depended on ensuring that their products were free of genetically altered ingredients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alarmed that genetically engineered crops may be finding their way into organic and natural foods, an industry group has begun a campaign to test products and label those that are largely free of biotech ingredients.

articles.headline: Kennedy’s Closest Confidante, in Politics and Life
articles.snippet: Edward M. Kennedy’s relationship with his wife, Vicki, defined the final years of his life.
articles.abstract: Edward M. Kennedy’s relationship with his wife, Vicki, defined the final years of his life.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  It was 1991, the worst year of Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s life since Chappaquiddick, 22 years earlier. With scandal unfolding that spring in Palm Beach, Fla., involving his nephew, the senator was humiliated by tabloid photos that showed him in a nightshirt after their boys’ night out, an aging, dissolute playboy.

articles.headline: Utah Gets Tough With Texting Drivers
articles.snippet: Under a new state law, texting motorists who cause traffic fatalities could be imprisoned for as long as 15 years and fined $10,000.
articles.abstract: Under a new state law, texting motorists who cause traffic fatalities could be imprisoned for as long as 15 years and fined $10,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOGAN, Utah  In most states, if somebody is texting behind the wheel and causes a crash that injures or kills someone, the penalty can be as light as a fine.

articles.headline: Fresh Air in the Muni Market
articles.snippet: Regulators are requiring debt issuers and brokerage firms to expand financial disclosures on a timely basis.
articles.abstract: Regulators are requiring debt issuers and brokerage firms to expand financial disclosures on a timely basis.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE municipal bond market may finally be coming out of the Dark Ages.

articles.headline: After Century of Growth, Tide Turns in Florida
articles.snippet: The Sunshine State, whose economy is tied to population growth, is in a pall after taking hits during the recession.
articles.abstract: The Sunshine State, whose economy is tied to population growth, is in a pall after taking hits during the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.  The smiling couple barreling ahead on the cover of Liberty magazine in 1926 knew exactly where to go. “Florida or Bust,” said the white paint on the car doors. “Four wheels, no brakes.”

articles.headline: Hey, PC, Who Taught You to Fight Back?
articles.snippet: After taking a beating in the “Get a Mac” ads, Microsoft is emphasizing the diversity of PC users and the value of Windows machines.
articles.abstract: After taking a beating in the “Get a Mac” ads, Microsoft is emphasizing the diversity of PC users and the value of Windows machines.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEAN SILER would never be mistaken for a movie star. A former Navy officer who wears glasses and is a tad on the heavy side, Mr. Siler works at Microsoft, where he oversees the Windows division’s adoption of new Internet connectivity software called IPv6.

articles.headline: Wiggling Their Toes at the Shoe Giants
articles.snippet: Upstart companies are challenging the running-shoe status quo with thin-sole designs meant to combine the benefits of going barefoot with a layer of protection.
articles.abstract: Upstart companies are challenging the running-shoe status quo with thin-sole designs meant to combine the benefits of going barefoot with a layer of protection.
articles.lead_paragraph: TODD BYERS was among more than 20,000 people running the San Francisco Marathon last month. Dressed in shorts and a T-shirt, he might have blended in with the other runners, except for one glaring difference: he was barefoot.

articles.headline: U.S. Says Pakistan Made Changes to Missiles Sold for Defense
articles.snippet: The U.S. has accused Pakistan of illegally modifying American-made missiles to expand its capability to strike land targets, a potential threat to India, officials said.
articles.abstract: The U.S. has accused Pakistan of illegally modifying American-made missiles to expand its capability to strike land targets, a potential threat to India, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States has accused Pakistan of illegally modifying American-made missiles to expand its capability to strike land targets, a potential threat to India, according to senior administration and Congressional officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Revisit ‘Hillary’ Documentary
articles.snippet: The new argument in the momentous case could transform the way political campaigns are conducted.
articles.abstract: The new argument in the momentous case could transform the way political campaigns are conducted.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court will cut short its summer break in early September to hear a new argument in a momentous case that could transform the way political campaigns are conducted.

articles.headline: Kennedy Mourners Memorialize ‘Soul of the Democratic Party’
articles.snippet: Hundreds of mourners, including President Obama, gathered to honor Edward M. Kennedy, who was buried in Arlington National Cemetery.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of mourners, including President Obama, gathered to honor Edward M. Kennedy, who was buried in Arlington National Cemetery.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va.  The nation said final farewell on Saturday to Edward M. Kennedy, who used his privileged life to give consistent, passionate voice to the underprivileged for nearly a half-century as a United States senator from Massachusetts. He was the only one of four fabled Kennedy brothers to reach late adulthood, and he was remembered for making the most of it.

articles.headline: With Bold Stand, Japan Opposition Wins a Landslide
articles.snippet: The Democratic Party of Japan has promised to reverse the economic decline and redefine Tokyo’s relationship with the U.S.
articles.abstract: The Democratic Party of Japan has promised to reverse the economic decline and redefine Tokyo’s relationship with the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan’s voters cast out the Liberal Democratic Party for only the second time in postwar history on Sunday, handing a landslide victory to a party that campaigned on a promise to reverse a generation-long economic decline and to redefine Tokyo’s relationship with Washington.

articles.headline: Cheney Offers Sharp Defense of C.I.A. Interrogation Tactics
articles.snippet: Former Vice President Dick Cheney sharply criticized the Obama administration’s decision to investigate the abuse of prisoners.
articles.abstract: Former Vice President Dick Cheney sharply criticized the Obama administration’s decision to investigate the abuse of prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Dick Cheney on Sunday sharply criticized the Obama administration’s decision to investigate the abuse of prisoners held by the Central Intelligence Agency as he delivered a forceful defense of the full range of interrogation techniques used by intelligence officers.

articles.headline: Tribune Chief May Remain for the Cleanup
articles.snippet: As the Tribune Company emerges from bankruptcy, it could keep the same management that led it there.
articles.abstract: As the Tribune Company emerges from bankruptcy, it could keep the same management that led it there.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company could well emerge from bankruptcy this fall with much of its current top management intact, according to people briefed on restructuring plans, but it remains unclear whether that might include the top dog himself, Samuel Zell, the chairman and chief executive who took the company private.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: You’re Gone. But Hey, You Can Reapply.
articles.snippet: Employees at The Journal News in Westchester County were told to reapply for their jobs, but in the end there would be 70 fewer positions.
articles.abstract: Employees at The Journal News in Westchester County were told to reapply for their jobs, but in the end there would be 70 fewer positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Aug. 12, the employees of The Journal News, a Westchester daily owned by Gannett, were told that there would be further staff reductions at the daily paper, which covers Westchester, Putnam and Rockland counties in New York. No surprise there.

articles.headline: Some Analysts See an End to Market Rally
articles.snippet: Art Cashin, the director of floor operations at UBS, said, “The people who know are getting out early.” The ratio of insider selling to insider buying soared to 30 to 1 in August.
articles.abstract: Art Cashin, the director of floor operations at UBS, said, “The people who know are getting out early.” The ratio of insider selling to insider buying soared to 30 to 1 in August.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been a blockbuster summer for the bulls on Wall Street. Shares are up more than 15 percent since mid-July, investors are feeling optimistic, and once-idle money is pouring back into equities.

articles.headline: Growing Accounts of Fraud Cloud Afghan Election
articles.snippet: International election observers who have been working for months in Afghanistan said the problem was systemic and institutional corruption.
articles.abstract: International election observers who have been working for months in Afghanistan said the problem was systemic and institutional corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUL-I-CHARKHI, Afghanistan  A Kabul teacher assigned to run a polling station in this village arrived at 6 a.m. on Election Day to find the ballot boxes already full, well before the voting was to start. When he protested, the other election officials told him to let it go; when he refused, he was taken away by the local tribal chieftain’s bodyguards.

articles.headline: A Hired Gun for Microsoft, in Pursuit of Google
articles.snippet: An engineer who chased after Google for 10 years while at Yahoo is returning to his mission at Microsoft.
articles.abstract: An engineer who chased after Google for 10 years while at Yahoo is returning to his mission at Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash.  Qi Lu knows as well as anyone just how difficult it is to take on Google.

articles.headline: Invisible Immigrants, Old and Left With ‘Nobody to Talk To’
articles.snippet: Older immigrants, cut off from society by language and culture differences, are now America’s fastest-growing immigrant group.
articles.abstract: Older immigrants, cut off from society by language and culture differences, are now America’s fastest-growing immigrant group.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREMONT, Calif.  They gather five days a week at a mall called the Hub, sitting on concrete planters and sipping thermoses of chai. These elderly immigrants from India are members of an all-male group called The 100 Years Living Club. They talk about crime in nearby Oakland, the cheapest flights to Delhi and how to deal with recalcitrant daughters-in-law.

articles.headline: Still in Development: A Film Culture in Dubai
articles.snippet: Persian Gulf cities have proved more able to build expensive facilities than to actually lure production to the Middle East, as economic efforts run up against their traditional values.
articles.abstract: Persian Gulf cities have proved more able to build expensive facilities than to actually lure production to the Middle East, as economic efforts run up against their traditional values.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  When the heiress Paris Hilton traveled here in June and July to audition female friends for her show “My New BFF,” her producers had access to state-of-the-art studios and a government eager to import a touch of Hollywood glamour to the Middle East.

articles.headline: As Banks Repay Bailout Money, U.S. Sees a Profit
articles.snippet: The profits, about $4 billion, have come from eight of the biggest banks that have fully repaid their bailout obligations to the government.
articles.abstract: The profits, about $4 billion, have come from eight of the biggest banks that have fully repaid their bailout obligations to the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after the federal rescue of the nation’s biggest banks, taxpayers have begun seeing profits from the hundreds of billions of dollars in aid that many critics thought might never be seen again.

articles.headline: Disney Swoops Into Action, Buying Marvel for $4 Billion
articles.snippet: Disney’s acquisition of Marvel Entertainment will also add Spider-Man and Captain America to its array of businesses.
articles.abstract: Disney’s acquisition of Marvel Entertainment will also add Spider-Man and Captain America to its array of businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company’s surprise deal to acquire Marvel Entertainment for $4 billion redraws the architecture of Hollywood and spotlights how the media giant has become more aggressive than its peers about growth.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply
